value:
We are all Homo sapiens Homo Sapiens (Stringer, Chris, 2016) and by exploring the search for our earliest common ancestor with Homo neanderthalensis (Stringer, Chris, 2016) we can deepen our understanding of our species' family tree. While this may seem like a simplification, it provides a clear demonstration of our shared humanity.

While animal evolution unfolds over vast stretches of time, punctuated by occasional bursts of rapid change (Sperling, Erik A., et Richard G. Stockey, 2018, pp. 605-622), the evolution of language (Fitch, W.T., 2017, 3-33) progresses swiftly. This rapid linguistic evolution enables us to categorize and label groups of people, inadvertently fostering the perception of differences among us.

content.desc: Here are the groups of people (families) studied

value.name: American Indigenous
value.desc: These are individuals who inhabited the Americas for millennia before the arrival of Europeans.

value.name: Mussulman
value.desc: These are families that [supposedly] have Muslim ancestors

value.name: People defamed as Jews
value.desc: This refers to individuals who lacked recent Jewish ancestry but were nonetheless labeled as Jews by others. The term defamation harkens back to the era of the Inquisition and should not be applied in the same manner today.

value.name: Slavery people
value.desc: These families have at least one ancestor who was enslaved.
